result.markdown:
--- title: "Advanced
website features" format: revealjs: theme: [simple, ../../css/slide-styles.scss, brand] title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: ../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg data-background-opacity: "0.5" data-background-gradient: "linear-gradient(30deg, {{< brand color pink >}}, {{< brand color yellow >}})" style: "text-align: left; right: 10%" # data-background-color: "{{< brand color blue >}}" include-in-header: - text: | --- # Other
common features {background-color='{{< brand color pink >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5'} ## URLs The website will mirror your file structure, including subdirectories . . . ::: {style="text-align: center"} [**/about.qmd**]{style='color: {{< brand color orange >}}'}
↓
[**example.com/about.html**]{style='color: {{< brand color blue >}}'} ::: . . . \ ::: {style="text-align: center"} [**/research/project1.qmd**]{style='color: {{< brand color orange >}}'}
↓
[**example.com/research/project1.html**]{style='color: {{< brand color blue >}}'} ::: ## Custom URLs What if you want nicer URLs? \ ::: {style="text-align: center"} [**example.com/about/**]{style='color: {{< brand color blue >}}'} [**example.com/research/project1/**]{style='color: {{< brand color blue >}}'} ::: ## `index.html` By convention, web servers treat `index.html` files in a special way. \ ::: {style="text-align: center"} [**example.com/about/**]{style='color: {{< brand color blue >}}'} implicitly means [**example.com/about/index.html**]{style='color: {{< brand color blue >}}'} ::: ## `index.qmd` If you want [**example.com/about/**]{style='color: {{< brand color blue >}}'}, put your about page in a folder named [**about**]{style='color: {{< brand color orange >}}'} and rename it to [**index.qmd**]{style='color: {{< brand color orange >}}'}. \ ::: {style="text-align: center"} [**/about.qmd**]{style='color: {{< brand color orange >}}'}
↓
[**/about/index.qmd**]{style='color: {{< brand color orange >}}'}
↓
[**example.com/about/**]{style='color: {{< brand color blue >}}'} ::: ## User-friendly URLs You could have a blog post like this (ew): ::: {style="text-align: center"} [**/2025-10-16_blog-post-title.qmd**]{style='color: {{< brand color orange >}}'}
↓
[**example.com/2025-10-16_blog-post-title.html**]{style='color: {{< brand color blue >}}'} ::: \ Or like this (yay): ::: {style="text-align: center"} [**/blog/2025/10/16/blog-post-title/index.qmd**]{style='color: {{< brand color orange >}}'}
↓
[**example.com/blog/2025/10/16/blog-post-title/**]{style='color: {{< brand color blue >}}'} ::: ## Your turn {background-color='{{< brand color cyan >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5'} 1. Make your `about.qmd` page appear at `about/` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
05:00
``` ::: ::: ## Page layout {.smaller} **Page layouts** - `article`: Default layout with main text area between 600px–900px - `full`: Expand main text area into the sidebar and margin area if there's no content there - `custom`: Provide your own HTML template for the main text area :::: {.columns} ::: {.column} **Component widths** ![](img/grid.png) ::: ::: {.column} **YAML settings** ```{.yaml code-line-numbers="false"} format: html: page-layout: article # or "full" or "custom" grid: sidebar-width: 300px body-width: 900px margin-width: 300px gutter-width: 1.5rem ``` ::: :::: ## Your turn {background-color='{{< brand color cyan >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5' .smaller} 1. Change the page layout settings for one of your page 2. *Bonus task!* Try using the Bootstrap CSS Grid layout system with `page-layout: custom`. - [See the documentation here](https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/page-layout.html#custom) - [See an IRL example here](https://bayesf22.classes.andrewheiss.com/#main-readings) ([and code here](https://github.com/andrewheiss/bayesf22.classes.andrewheiss.com/blob/8e994b538dc7c4f334a898f1475e6edada4ec6d5/index.qmd#L95)) **Advice**: - Don't try to make all these changes at once! Remember the workflow: edit, save, preview, repeat. - Use the documentation at [Quarto.org \> Guide \> Advanced \> Page Layout](https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/page-layout.html). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
10:00
``` ::: ::: ## Article layout Quarto offers *a ton* of article-specific layout options: - Make content go into the margin - Make content go across the whole page - Put content in the margins ![](img/article-layout-documentation.png){fig-align="center"} ## Your turn {background-color='{{< brand color cyan >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5' .smaller} 1. Add an image that spans across the whole page 2. Add some text to the margin **Advice**: - Don't try to make all these changes at once! Remember the workflow: edit, save, preview, repeat. - Use the documentation at [Quarto.org \> Guide \> Authoring \> Article Layout](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/article-layout.html). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
10:00
``` ::: ::: # Freezing {background-color='{{< brand color pink >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5'} ## Re-running code :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ````{.markdown filename="your-document.qmd"} --- title: "My Complex Document" format: html --- Here we run all our models and then plot them: ```{{r}} # Intensive code! ``` ```{{r}} # Intensive code! ``` ```{{r}} # Intensive code! ``` ```` ::: ::: {.column width="3%"} ::: ::: {.column width="47%"} ::: {.incremental} - Sometimes you'll have a lot of code chunks that take a long time to run. - Quarto will re-run these chunks each time you render the site. - Good for reproducibility! Bad for speed! ::: ::: ::::: ## Freeze computational output :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ````{.markdown filename="your-document.qmd" code-line-numbers="4-5"} --- title: "My Complex Document" format: html execute: freeze: auto --- Here we run all our models and then plot them: ```{{r}} # Intensive code! ``` ```{{r}} # Intensive code! ``` ```{{r}} # Intensive code! ``` ```` ::: ::: {.column width="3%"} ::: ::: {.column width="47%"} Use `freeze: auto` to only re-run the code if the source file changes. ← Individual files
or site-wide ↓ ````{.yaml filename="_quarto.yml" code-line-numbers="4-5"} project: type: website execute: freeze: auto website: title: "Example site" ```` ::: ::::: ## Freeze computational output Code output is stored in `_freeze` ![](img/freeze-output.png){fig-align="center"} ## Freezing ≠ caching ::: {.incremental} - Freezing *only* stores the text of the code output. - Changing the file will force a re-run. - Consider caching if you don't want the code to re-run (see [documentation](https://quarto.org/docs/projects/code-execution.html#cache)): ```{.yaml code-line-numbers="false"} execute: cache: true ``` ::: # Listings {background-color='{{< brand color pink >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5'} ## Automatic content We can automatically add all the pages in a folder to a sidebar: ::::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ```` {.yaml filename="_quarto.yml" code-line-numbers="6-10"} website: sidebar: contents: - href: index.qmd text: Home - section: Research contents: - research/project1.qmd - research/project2.qmd - research/project3.qmd ```` ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ```` {.yaml filename="_quarto.yml" code-line-numbers="6-7"} website: sidebar: contents: - href: index.qmd text: Home - section: Research contents: research/* ```` ::: ::::: . . . **What if we want fancier automatic pages?** ::: footer Documentation: {target="_blank"} ::: ## Listing pages ::::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} \ ```` {.markdown filename="research.qmd" code-line-numbers="3-5"} --- title: "Research" listing: contents: "*.qmd" type: table --- ```` ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ![](img/listing-example.png){width="100%"} ::: ::::: ::: footer Documentation: {target="_blank"} ::: ## Your turn {background-color='{{< brand color cyan >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5' .smaller} 1. Edit `research/index.qmd` to be a listing page, showing all the pages in the `research` folder. 2. Experiment with changing the listing type to `default`, then `table`, then `grid`. **Advice**: - Don't try to make all these changes at once! Remember the workflow: edit, save, preview, repeat. - Use the documentation at [Quarto.org \> Guide \> Websites \> Listing Pages](https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-listings.html). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
10:00
``` ::: ::: ## Metadata in listings :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} ![](img/listing-metadata.png){fig-align="center" style="box-shadow: 5px 5px 15px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); border-radius: 5px;"} ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ```` {.markdown filename="post.qmd"} --- title: "Research" author: "Your name" description: "Something" date: 2025-10-06 image: "img/thing.jpg" --- ```` ::: :::: ## Your turn {background-color='{{< brand color cyan >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5' .smaller} 1. Add metadata to your different research `.qmd` files, including images. See how those are reflected in the listing page after rendering. 2. *Bonus task!* Modify how the listing page is sorted. Sort it by descending title. - [See the documentation here](https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-listings.html#sorting-items) 3. *Bonus task!* Change how the dates are shown in the listing page with the `date-format` option. - [See the documentation here](https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-listings.html#advanced-options) **Advice**: - Don't try to make all these changes at once! Remember the workflow: edit, save, preview, repeat. - Use the documentation at [Quarto.org \> Guide \> Websites \> Document Listings](https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-listings.html). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
10:00
``` ::: ::: ## Categories ![](img/listing-categories.png){fig-align="center" style="box-shadow: 5px 5px 15px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); border-radius: 5px;"} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%" .fragment} **Enable categories in the listing settings** ```` {.yaml filename="listing-page.qmd"} listing: categories: true ```` ::: ::: {.column width="50%" .fragment} **Specify categories in the document** ```` {.markdown filename="post.qmd" code-line-numbers="3-6"} --- title: "Research" categories: - statistics - r - tidyverse --- ```` ::: :::: ## Your turn {background-color='{{< brand color cyan >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5' .smaller} 1. Add categories to your different research `.qmd` files. See how those are reflected in the listing page after rendering. 2. *Bonus task!* Change the category lisit on the listing page to appear as a word cloud. - [See the documentation here](https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-listings.html#categories) **Advice**: - Don't try to make all these changes at once! Remember the workflow: edit, save, preview, repeat. - Use the documentation at [Quarto.org \> Guide \> Websites \> Document Listings \> Categories](https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-listings.html#categories). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
10:00
``` ::: ::: ## Extra advanced bonus stuff **Multiple listings** Include lists of different document types on the same page ([example](https://www.andrewheiss.com/research/) + [code](https://github.com/andrewheiss/ath-quarto/blob/main/research/index.qmd)) . . . **Custom listings** Go beyond `default`, `table`, and `grid` and make your own template ([example](https://www.andrewheiss.com/research/) + [code](https://github.com/andrewheiss/ath-quarto/blob/main/html/research/listing.ejs)) . . . **YAML lists** Generate listings of items in a YAML file isntead of `.qmd` files ([example](https://www.andrewheiss.com/teaching/ + [code](https://github.com/andrewheiss/ath-quarto/blob/main/teaching/index.qmd) + [custom listing code](https://github.com/andrewheiss/ath-quarto/blob/main/html/teaching/listing.ejs))) ## Your turn {background-color='{{< brand color cyan >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5' .smaller} **Make a blog!** 1. Create a new folder named `blog` with a file named `index.qmd` in it. 2. Make a few folders and files named `blog/2025/10/16/thing/index.qmd`, etc. 3. Add some fake content in the blog posts. Add images, titles, descriptions, etc. 4. Make the blog posts appear as a listing page at `blog/index.qmd`. 5. Add `blog/index.qmd` to your top navigation bar. **Advice**: - Don't try to make all these changes at once! Remember the workflow: edit, save, preview, repeat. - Use the documentation at [Quarto.org \> Guide \> Websites \> Document Listings](https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-listings.html). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
20:00
``` ::: ::: # Extensions {background-color='{{< brand color pink >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5'} ## Extensions Quarto has [extensions](https://quarto.org/docs/extensions/) that let you add custom… - shortcodes - filters - document formats and templates - brands ## Shortcode extensions {.smaller} **Font Awesome icons** ([site](https://fontawesome.com/) + [extension](https://github.com/quarto-ext/fontawesome)) ```{.bash filename="Terminal" code-line-numbers="false"} quarto add quarto-ext/fontawesome ``` \ | Text | Output | |:-----|:------:| | `{{{< fa home >}}}` | {{< fa home >}} | | `{{{< fa wand-magic-sparkles >}}}` | {{< fa wand-magic-sparkles >}} | | `{{{< fa brands apple >}}}` | {{< fa brands apple >}} | | `{{{< fa brands r-project >}}}` | {{< fa brands r-project >}} | | `{{{< fa globe >}}}` | {{< fa globe >}} | : {tbl-colwidths="[75,25]"} ## Use in Markdown: ````{.markdown filename="my-document.qmd" code-line-numbers="false"} - {{{< fa book >}}} [Book page](https://www.bayesrulesbook.com/) - {{{< fa person-chalkboard >}}} [Teaching resources](https://bayes-rules.github.io/posts/resources/) - {{{< fa brands r-project >}}} [R package](https://github.com/bayes-rules/bayesrules) and [package documentation](https://bayes-rules.github.io/bayesrules/docs/) - {{{< fa brands youtube >}}} Alicia Johnson, ["Bayes Rules! An Introduction to Bayesian Modeling with R with Alicia Johnson"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MgB1ihuEDN4), presentation for R-Ladies Philly on October 18, 2021 ```` . . . ::: {style="text-align: center"} ↓ ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em"} > - {{< fa book >}} [Book page](https://www.bayesrulesbook.com/) > - {{< fa house >}} [Project page](https://bayes-rules.github.io/) > - {{< fa brands r-project >}} [R package](https://github.com/bayes-rules/bayesrules) and [package documentation](https://bayes-rules.github.io/bayesrules/docs/) > - {{< fa brands youtube >}} Alicia Johnson, ["Bayes Rules! An Introduction to Bayesian Modeling with R with Alicia Johnson"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MgB1ihuEDN4), presentation for R-Ladies Philly on October 18, 2021 ::: ## Use in YAML: ````{.yaml filename="_quarto.yml" code-line-numbers="false"} website: navbar: left: - text: "{{{< fa person-chalkboard >}}} Teaching" href: teaching.qmd - text: "{{{< fa flask >}}} Research" href: research.qmd right: - text: "{{{< fa brands google-scholar >}}}" href: "https://example.com" ```` . . . ::: {style="text-align: center"} ↓ ::: ![](img/fa-navbar.png){fig-align="center"} ## Filter extensions **Preview Color** ([extension](https://github.com/mcanouil/quarto-preview-colour)) ```{.bash filename="Terminal" code-line-numbers="false"} quarto add mcanouil/quarto-preview-colour ``` Enable in YAML, either for one page or site-wide: ````{.yaml code-line-numbers="false"} filters: - preview-colour ```` . . . \ ::: {style="font-size: 0.8em;"} We use `#1696d2` for Democrats and and `#db2b27` for Republicans. ::: . . . ::: {style="text-align: center"} ↓ ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.8em;"} ```{=html}

We use #1696d2◉ for Democrats and and #db2b27◉ for Republicans.

``` ::: ## Lots of others! {.smaller} There are hundreds of extensions: find them all at [Quarto.org \> Extensions](https://quarto.org/docs/extensions/) or at [the Quarto Extensions directory](https://m.canouil.dev/quarto-extensions/). Here are some common extensions for websites specifically: | Extension | Description | |--------------------------|----------------------------------------------| | [Font Awesome](https://github.com/quarto-ext/fontawesome) | Include [Font Awesome](https://fontawesome.com/) icons | | [Academicons](https://github.com/schochastics/academicons) | Include [academicons](https://jpswalsh.github.io/academicons/) icons | | [Custom Callouts](https://quarto.thecoatlessprofessor.com/custom-callout/) | Go beyond Quarto's default `note`, `warning`, `important`, `tip`, and `caution` callouts | | [Preview Color](https://github.com/mcanouil/quarto-preview-colour) | Add little circles to show hex colors | | [Embed PDFs](https://github.com/jmgirard/embedpdf) | Easily embed PDF files in HTML documents | | [Downloadthis](https://github.com/shafayetShafee/downloadthis) | Create download buttons | : {tbl-colwidths="[30,70]"} ## Your turn {background-color='{{< brand color cyan >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5' .smaller} 1. Install the [Font Awesome extension](https://github.com/quarto-ext/fontawesome) in your website project. 2. Use Font Awesome shortcodes: - Include a Font Awesome icon in your navigation bar - Include a Font Awesome icon in the text of one of your pages 3. Install another Quarto extension and play around with it. **Advice**: - Don't try to make all these changes at once! Remember the workflow: edit, save, preview, repeat. - Use the documentation at the [Font Awesome extension page](https://github.com/quarto-ext/fontawesome) and [Quarto.org \> Extensions](https://quarto.org/docs/extensions/). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
10:00
``` ::: ::: # What's next? {background-color='{{< brand color yellow >}}' background-image='../../img/background-hex-shapes.svg' background-opacity='0.5'} ## Course outline - ✅ ~~Intro to Quarto~~ - ✅ ~~Creating basic websites~~ - ✅ ~~Advanced website features~~ - Publishing - Customization and branding - Interactivity

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
